title: 113_hr4966
content: The Act titled "Pathogen Reduction and Testing Reform Act of 2014" addresses the adulteration of products containing certain pathogens or contaminants. The Federal Meat Inspection Act is amended to include microbial pathogens associated with serious illness or death in meat products. Additionally, strains of pathogens like Campylobacter or Salmonella resistant to two important antibiotics are prohibited in meat products. The Poultry Products Inspection Act is amended to include microbial pathogens associated with serious illness or death in poultry products. Additionally, poultry products must not contain strains of pathogens resistant to two critically important antibiotics for human medicine. The Poultry Products Inspection Act is amended to include microbial pathogens resistant to two critically important antibiotics for human medicine in poultry products. The Egg Products Inspection Act is amended to include microbial pathogens resistant to two critically important antibiotics in eggs and egg products. The Egg Products Inspection Act is amended to include microbial pathogens resistant to two critically important antibiotics in eggs and egg products. The amendment specifies the antibiotics listed by the World Health Organization and updates the language regarding subparagraphs in the Act. SEC. 3. TESTING FOR CERTAIN PATHOGENS OR CONTAMINANTS REQUIRED. The Federal Meat Inspection Act is amended to include testing for certain pathogens or contaminants in meat and meat food products. The Federal Meat Inspection Act is amended to require testing for certain pathogens or contaminants in meat and meat food products. The Secretary must establish sampling protocols and testing procedures to determine adulteration and prevent the use of adulterated products in commerce. The Poultry Products Inspection Act is also amended to include similar testing requirements. The Secretary must establish sampling protocols and testing procedures to determine adulteration in poultry and poultry products, as well as prevent the entry of adulterated products into commerce. The Egg Products Inspection Act is also amended to include similar testing requirements. The Secretary is required to establish sampling protocols and testing procedures to detect adulteration in eggs and egg products within one year of the enactment of this section. This is to prevent the entry of adulterated products into commerce. The Secretary of Agriculture must issue regulations within 18 months of the Act's enactment to implement the amendments. The amendments will apply to meat, poultry, eggs, and their products entering interstate or foreign commerce after the Act's enactment date.
